content.title: IS-LM Model
content.definition: The IS-LM model is a macroeconomic framework developed by John Hicks (1937) to interpret Keynes's General Theory. It shows how the goods market (IS curve) and money market (LM curve) simultaneously determine equilibrium output (Y) and interest rate (r). The IS curve represents goods market equilibrium where investment equals saving; it slopes downward because lower interest rates stimulate investment and output. The LM curve represents money market equilibrium where money demand equals money supply; it slopes upward because higher income increases money demand, requiring higher interest rates for equilibrium. The intersection determines the economy's short-run equilibrium.

definitions_glossary.is_curve: Investment-Saving curve - locus of (Y, r) combinations where goods market is in equilibrium (AD = Y)
definitions_glossary.lm_curve: Liquidity preference-Money supply curve - locus of (Y, r) where money market is in equilibrium (Md = Ms)
definitions_glossary.goods_market: Market for all final goods and services - equilibrium requires total spending (C+I+G+NX) equals output (Y)
definitions_glossary.money_market: Market for money balances - equilibrium requires money demand (liquidity preference) equals money supply
definitions_glossary.investment: I = I₀ - hr where I₀ is autonomous investment and h is interest sensitivity of investment
definitions_glossary.consumption: C = C₀ + MPC(Y - T) where C₀ is autonomous consumption, MPC is marginal propensity to consume
definitions_glossary.money_demand: Md/P = kY - lr where k is income sensitivity and l is interest sensitivity (liquidity preference)
definitions_glossary.money_supply: Ms/P = M/P - real money supply controlled by central bank
definitions_glossary.equilibrium_output: Y* where IS and LM curves intersect - both goods and money markets clear simultaneously
definitions_glossary.equilibrium_interest_rate: r* where IS and LM curves intersect - rate that clears both markets
definitions_glossary.fiscal_policy: Changes in G or T that shift the IS curve - government's demand-side tool
definitions_glossary.monetary_policy: Changes in money supply M that shift the LM curve - central bank's tool
definitions_glossary.crowding_out: When fiscal expansion raises interest rates, reducing private investment - partial offset of stimulus

key_points: IS curve: Goods market equilibrium. Derivation: Y = C(Y-T) + I(r) + G. Lower r → higher I → higher Y. Downward sloping.
LM curve: Money market equilibrium. Derivation: M/P = L(Y, r). Higher Y → higher money demand → higher r needed. Upward sloping.
Equilibrium: Intersection of IS and LM determines Y* and r* simultaneously - both markets clear
Fiscal policy: Increase G or decrease T → IS shifts right → higher Y and higher r
Monetary policy: Increase M → LM shifts right → higher Y and lower r
Crowding out: Fiscal expansion raises r, reducing I. Partial offset of multiplier. Steeper LM → more crowding out.
Liquidity trap: When LM horizontal (r at zero), monetary policy ineffective. Fiscal policy fully effective (no crowding out).
Classical case: When LM vertical (money demand insensitive to r), fiscal policy ineffective. Monetary policy fully effective.
Policy mix: Fiscal and monetary policy can achieve same Y with different r (and different composition of output).
IS-LM underlies AD curve: Each P level gives different LM, hence different equilibrium Y. Trace out AD curve.

examples.title: Fiscal Stimulus - IS Shift Right
examples.description: Government increases spending by $100 billion. IS curve shifts right by multiplier × ΔG = 4 × $100B = $400B (if MPC=0.75, multiplier=4). But this is NOT the actual output increase. As Y rises, money demand rises, pushing up interest rates (move up LM curve). Higher r reduces investment (crowding out). Final equilibrium: Y increases less than $400B, r is higher. Steeper LM → more crowding out → smaller Y increase.
examples.context: Fiscal policy with crowding out - IS-LM mechanics
examples.data: If horizontal LM (liquidity trap): ΔY = $400B, Δr = 0. If vertical LM (classical): ΔY = $0, Δr maximal.

examples.title: Monetary Expansion - LM Shift Right
examples.description: Fed increases money supply via open market purchase. LM curve shifts right - at each Y, lower r needed for money market equilibrium. New equilibrium: higher Y, lower r. Lower rates stimulate investment. No crowding out (r falls, not rises). BUT if in liquidity trap (horizontal LM), additional money simply held - no effect on r or Y. Monetary policy 'pushing on a string.'
examples.context: Monetary policy in IS-LM - comparing to fiscal policy
examples.data: Normal times: Increase M → lower r → higher I → higher Y. Liquidity trap (r=0): Increase M → no change in r or Y

examples.title: 2008-2009 Liquidity Trap
examples.description: Fed cut federal funds rate to 0-0.25% by December 2008. LM curve essentially horizontal at zero lower bound. Further monetary expansion (QE) had limited effect on rates/output through interest rate channel. Fiscal policy (ARRA stimulus) had full multiplier effect - no crowding out at zero rates. IS shift right translated directly to output increase. Textbook liquidity trap case demonstrated in practice.
examples.context: Real-world liquidity trap validating IS-LM predictions
examples.data: Fed funds rate: 0-0.25% (2008-2015). ARRA multiplier estimates: 1.5-2.0 (higher than normal - no crowding out)

examples.title: Policy Mix - Volcker-Reagan Era
examples.description: Early 1980s: Tight monetary policy (LM left) to fight inflation + expansionary fiscal policy (tax cuts, defense spending - IS right). Result: Very high real interest rates (r rose to ~8-9%), output recovered but crowded out private investment. Same output achievable with different mix: easier money + tighter fiscal → lower r, more investment. The policy mix determines not just Y but composition (G vs I).
examples.context: Policy mix affecting interest rates and output composition
examples.data: Real interest rates: 8-9% (1980s) vs 2-3% (1970s). Investment share of GDP declined. Budget deficits expanded.

examples.title: IS-LM Derivation of AD Curve
examples.description: How IS-LM generates the AD curve: (1) Start with P₁, find IS-LM equilibrium Y₁. (2) Increase P to P₂. Real money supply M/P falls. LM shifts left. New equilibrium Y₂ < Y₁ at higher r. (3) Plot (P₁, Y₁) and (P₂, Y₂) - this is the AD curve. Higher P → lower Y (downward-sloping AD). Any fiscal/monetary policy that shifts IS or LM also shifts the AD curve.
examples.context: Connection between IS-LM and AD-AS framework
examples.data: IS-LM is the underlying structure; AD curve is the reduced-form relationship between P and Y

content.statement: The IS-LM model is the workhorse of short-run macroeconomic analysis, showing how goods and money markets jointly determine output and interest rates. It provides the theoretical foundation for understanding how fiscal and monetary policy affect the economy, including the phenomenon of crowding out and the special cases of liquidity trap and classical dichotomy.

explanation.intuition: Think of IS-LM as two markets talking to each other. The goods market says: 'If interest rates are low, businesses invest more, so we need more output.' The money market says: 'If output is high, people need more money for transactions, so interest rates must be high.' The IS curve captures the first relationship (low r → high Y). The LM curve captures the second (high Y → high r). Where they cross, both markets are satisfied - that's equilibrium. Fiscal policy (changing G or T) affects the goods market directly, shifting IS. Monetary policy (changing M) affects the money market directly, shifting LM. But because the markets are connected, each policy affects both Y and r.
explanation.key_insight: The crucial insight is crowding out - why fiscal policy is less powerful than the simple multiplier suggests. When government spends more, output and income rise, people want more money for transactions, so they sell bonds, bond prices fall, interest rates rise. Higher rates reduce private investment. So government spending 'crowds out' some private investment. The amount of crowding out depends on LM slope: flat LM (liquidity trap) → no crowding out → full multiplier. Steep LM (classical case) → complete crowding out → fiscal policy ineffective. This is why the effectiveness of fiscal policy depends on monetary conditions and the state of the economy.
explanation.technical_details: IS curve derivation: Start with Y = C + I + G. Let C = C₀ + c(Y-T), I = I₀ - dr. Substitute: Y = C₀ + c(Y-T) + I₀ - dr + G. Solve: Y(1-c) = C₀ - cT + I₀ - dr + G. So Y = [1/(1-c)][A - dr] where A = C₀ - cT + I₀ + G. This is IS: Y = f(r) with f'(r) < 0 (downward sloping). LM curve derivation: M/P = kY - hr (money demand). Solve for r: r = (kY - M/P)/h = (k/h)Y - (1/h)(M/P). This is LM: r = g(Y) with g'(Y) > 0 (upward sloping). Equilibrium: Solve IS and LM simultaneously for Y* and r*. Fiscal multiplier with crowding out: dY/dG = 1/[(1-c) + dk/h] < 1/(1-c).

mathematical_formulation.is_curve: Y = [1/(1-c)] × [C₀ - cT + I₀ + G - dr] or solving for r: r = (A - (1-c)Y)/d
mathematical_formulation.lm_curve: M/P = kY - hr or solving for r: r = (k/h)Y - (1/h)(M/P)

liquidity_trap.lm_curve: Horizontal at minimum r (zero lower bound)
liquidity_trap.fiscal_policy: Fully effective - no crowding out since r can't rise
liquidity_trap.monetary_policy: Ineffective - additional money hoarded, no impact on r or Y

classical_case.condition: h → 0 (money demand insensitive to interest rate)
classical_case.lm_curve: Vertical - Y determined solely by money supply
classical_case.fiscal_policy: Ineffective - complete crowding out, only changes r not Y

investment_trap.fiscal_policy: Fully effective - no crowding out since I doesn't respond to r
investment_trap.monetary_policy: Ineffective - can't influence spending through interest rates

lm_shifts_right: Increase in money supply M (Fed buys bonds)
Decrease in price level P (increases real money supply)

concepts: Simultaneous equations: Solving IS and LM for equilibrium

provenance.verification_notes: Content verified against Hicks (1937) original paper and standard textbooks. Mathematical derivations confirmed algebraically. Special cases (liquidity trap, classical) verified. Policy multiplier formulas derived and cross-checked.

verified_claims.claim: IS curve slopes downward in (Y, r) space
verified_claims.derivation: From IS: Y = [1/(1-c)][A - dr]. Take dY/dr = -d/(1-c) < 0 since d > 0, c ∈ (0,1). Downward sloping ✓

verified_claims.claim: LM curve slopes upward in (Y, r) space
verified_claims.derivation: From LM: r = (k/h)Y - (1/h)(M/P). Take dr/dY = k/h > 0 since k, h > 0. Upward sloping ✓

verified_claims.claim: Fiscal multiplier with crowding out is less than simple multiplier
verified_claims.derivation: dY/dG = h/[h(1-c) + dk]. Simple multiplier = 1/(1-c). Since dk > 0: h/[h(1-c) + dk] < h/[h(1-c)] = 1/(1-c) ✓

verified_claims.claim: In liquidity trap (h→∞), fiscal policy fully effective
verified_claims.derivation: lim(h→∞) dY/dG = lim(h→∞) h/[h(1-c) + dk] = lim h/[h(1-c)] = 1/(1-c) = simple multiplier ✓
